sect1.title: Dependencies
sect1.para: In order to run &hotpotato; you'll need only JDK 1.6 and &Netty;. Its heavily based on Netty so you'll be dealing with some of its HTTP classes and API's.
There was no real reason to hide this API just to spend useless CPU cycles converting between both lib's API's.

sect1.title: Your very first request
sect1.para: &hotpotato; is not about one-liners. This library comes pre-configured with sensible defaults that suit the majority of usages but still, you're strongly advised to learn more about fine tuning &hotpotato; in to suit it to your specific needs and extract maximum performance.
So without further ado, here's how to perform a request, quick & dirty.

callout.para: Every client must be initialised before being used. By default, you can simply call init() on a new instance without configuration. We'll address configuration later.
As a future reference, the same client can be used by multiple threads at the same time - that's kind of its purpose actually. So you might consider using the same instance across your application.
The HTTP requests are &Netty;'s API. Every header must be manually set prior to the execution request.

The request is executed by calling one of the variants of execute() on a initialised &HttpClient;. This returns a &HttpRequestFuture;. We'll cover the futures shortly so for now just keep in mind its what allows you to execute requests wither synchronously or asynchronously. Calling awaitUninterruptibly() on a future will cause the calling thread to halt until the future completes, either due to timeout, failure, success or cancelation. After the request is executed, the future is printed out to the console so you can see the response status.
For the sake of first example simplicity, this particular version of execute() discards the request result.
Every client should always be terminated once it's no longer necessary.

sect1.title: Processing responses
sect1.para: In the first example we discarded the response to our request. While you may encounter such cases, the odds are that in the vast majority of the situations you'll want to receive and process the contents of the response, either in the form of HTTP headers or body.

This is where &HttpResponseProcessor; comes in. This component will allow the &HttpClient; to determine whether the response body should be consumed or not, through willProcess() method. For each request you execute, you just pass along an implementation of this interface (that version of execute() we used on the previous example implicitly used an instance of this processor that simply discards anything) and its willProcess() method will be called. Should this method return true, addData() and addLastData() will be called as soon as new data arrives on the sockets.

&BodyAsStringResponseProcessor; is an example of such implementation. It reads the bytes received in the response and buffers them until the last piece of information is received. Once it arrives, it generates a string (hence its original name...)
Go ahead and run the previous example, replacing the line:
sect1.programlisting: HttpRequestFuture future = client.execute("hotpotato.factor45.org", 80, request, new BodyAsStringResponseProcessor());
sect1.para: This will effectively make the response be processed. You might want to see it, though. Add this right after the System.out.println() call in the previous example.

callout.para: Note that there is a difference between isSuccessful() and isSuccessfulResponse(). While the first will return true if the request completes, no matter which response code is received (200, 300, 400, ...), the second will only return true if the request completed and the response code was between 200 and 299 (inclusive).

sect1.title: Synchronous vs asynchronous
sect1.para:
Handling the response body happens transparently. Handling the results of the whole transaction, however, will have to be explicitly performed by the programmer. There are two ways to wait for a request to complete:
synchronously - blocking calls to execute()
asynchronously - non-blocking calls to execute()

sect2.title: Synchronous requests
sect2.para: Synchronous requests are requests whose calling thread (i.e. the thread that calls execute() on the &HttpClient; instance) will block by calling a variant of await(). Only when the &HttpRequestFuture; completes either through success, failure or cancellation will the calling thread be unlocked and normal execution continue, as shown below:

sect2.title: Asynchronous requests
sect2.para: Asyncronous requests allow the thread calling execute() on the &HttpClient; to adopt a fire-and-forget paradigm. It instructs the client to perform the request and provides a listener that will perform some computation as soon as the request completes. The important difference is that this is a non-blocking call, which means that this computation will take place on another thread (an internal thread of the &HttpClient; implementation) rather than on the thread calling execute().

sect1.title: Shutting down and cleaning resources
sect1.para:
&HttpClient; implementations
Well, actually there's just one, &DefaultHttpClient;... are very self-contained. In order to terminate an instance you simply call terminate() and it pretty much does the rest itself: cancels all pending requests, terminates all active connections and finished any &HttpRequestFuture;s left to be finished.

The only exception is when you add an external &TimeoutManager; to a &HttpClient; instance, which you will have to manually initialise and terminate. Other than that, simply calling terminate() will ensure all resources are properly released and any waiting threads will proceed.

sect1.title: Summary
sect1.para: In this chapter we covered the basics behind the usage of &hotpotato;. You've learned the lifecycle of a &HttpClient; instance: creation, initialisation, execution, termination. You also learned how to perform all sorts of requests and deal with responses.

&hotpotato; is configured with sensible defaults, which means you can pretty much just create a &DefaultHttpClient; and start firing away requests and you're guaranteed to have yourself a pretty fast and scalable Java HTTP client. However, as this library was developed to be used in servers rather than in clients - and since this usually means very specific use cases - it can be heavily configured as we will see in .
